5 Prepare folder and data 5.1 Set the working directory 5.2 List the files inside the working directory 5.3 Reading dataset from SPSS file (.sav)

5 Prepare folder and data 5.1 Set the working directory This can be done in 2 ways: Using codes Using point and click To use point and click, use the down arrow button next to More . Then click ‘Set as working directory’ 5.2 List the files inside the working directory All files will be displayed when you click ‘Files’. Or you can use this code, list.files() ## [1] "_book" "_bookdown_files" ## [3] "_main.Rmd" "_main_files" ## [5] "01-intro.knit.md" "01-intro.md" ## [7] "01-intro.Rmd" "01-intro.utf8.md" ## [9] "02-text.Rmd" "03-Grammar_of_Var.knit.md" ## [11] "03-Grammar_of_Var.md" "03-Grammar_of_Var.Rmd" ## [13] "03-Grammar_of_Var.utf8.md" "04-EDA_Graphs.Rmd" ## [15] "04-report.Rmd" "05-graphical.Rmd" ## [17] "06-references.Rmd" "07-summary.Rmd" ## [19] "book chapters.Rproj" "cholest.csv" ## [21] "cholest.dta" "cholest.sav" ## [23] "cholest.xlsx" "eye.csv" ## [25] "eye.dta" "eye.sav" ## [27] "eye.xlsx" "index.Rmd" ## [29] "metab1.csv" "metab1.dta" ## [31] "qol.csv" "qol.dta" ## [33] "qol.sav" "qol.xlsx" ## [35] "site" "Template_R_bookdown" 5.3 Reading dataset from SPSS file (.sav) Dataset in SPSS format will end with .sav. To read SPSS data into R we use ‘foreign’ library. Create a object to represent the SPSS data that we will read into R. library(foreign) dataSPSS<-read.spss('qol.sav', to.data.frame = TRUE) ## re-encoding from UTF-8

6 Describing data Let us examine the data str(dataSPSS) ## 'data.frame': 365 obs. of 13 variables: ## $ id : num 308 335 94 329 350 22 171 274 332 147 ... ## $ sex : Factor w/ 2 levels "female","male": 1 2 1 1 1 2 1 1 2 2 ... ## $ age : num 55 41 50 47 67 57 60 54 60 45 ... ## $ tahundx : num 14 4 5 10 13 4 4 15 13 3 ... ## $ tx : Factor w/ 4 levels "diet only","OHA and diet only",..: 3 4 2 4 4 2 2 2 4 2 ... ## $ group : Factor w/ 2 levels "\"group A\"",..: 2 2 1 2 2 1 1 1 2 1 ... ## $ complica : Factor w/ 2 levels "no","yes": 2 1 1 2 1 2 1 1 2 1 ... ## $ hba1c : num 8.1 8 7.5 9.4 11.7 8.1 7.5 9.2 NA NA ... ## $ fbs : num 6.9 4.8 8 3.6 12.5 8.5 NA NA NA NA ... ## $ rbs : num 16.7 7.4 13.2 7.4 NA 7.8 9.4 7.8 NA 12.4 ... ## $ tg_total : num 0.92 1.66 0.74 0.94 3.01 1.3 NA 1.9 NA NA ... ## $ choleste : num 7.09 2.91 5.94 3.27 7.1 3.54 NA 5.7 NA NA ... ## $ ADDQSCORE: num 0 -0.222 -0.333 -0.36 -0.44 ... ## - attr(*, "variable.labels")= Named chr "id_no" "sex" "" "" ... ## ..- attr(*, "names")= chr "id" "sex" "age" "tahundx" ... ## - attr(*, "codepage")= int 65001 Now, let us summarize our data summary(dataSPSS) ## id sex age tahundx ## Min. : 1.0 female:153 Min. :21.00 Min. : 1.000 ## 1st Qu.:126.0 male :212 1st Qu.:47.00 1st Qu.: 4.000 ## Median :227.0 Median :53.00 Median : 7.000 ## Mean :221.5 Mean :52.75 Mean : 8.795 ## 3rd Qu.:325.0 3rd Qu.:59.00 3rd Qu.:12.000 ## Max. :416.0 Max. :80.00 Max. :38.000 ## ## tx group complica hba1c ## diet only : 10 "group A":248 no :225 Min. : 4.100 ## OHA and diet only :238 "group B":117 yes:140 1st Qu.: 7.500 ## insulin and diet only: 26 Median : 9.050 ## all : 91 Mean : 9.301 ## 3rd Qu.:10.775 ## Max. :19.900 ## NA's :111 ## fbs rbs tg_total choleste ## Min. : 2.700 Min. : 3.900 Min. :0.380 Min. : 2.020 ## 1st Qu.: 5.700 1st Qu.: 7.925 1st Qu.:1.125 1st Qu.: 4.308 ## Median : 8.000 Median :11.300 Median :1.570 Median : 5.210 ## Mean : 9.003 Mean :12.045 Mean :2.002 Mean : 5.437 ## 3rd Qu.:11.900 3rd Qu.:15.000 3rd Qu.:2.385 3rd Qu.: 6.423 ## Max. :29.200 Max. :31.500 Max. :8.020 Max. :13.100 ## NA's :178 NA's :83 NA's :191 NA's :181 ## ADDQSCORE ## Min. :-9.000 ## 1st Qu.:-5.590 ## Median :-3.944 ## Mean :-4.179 ## 3rd Qu.:-2.556 ## Max. : 0.000 ##

7 Graphing or Plotting data 7.1 One variable: A categorical or factor variable 7.2 One variable: A numerical variable 7.3 Two variables : A numerical with another numerical variable 7.4 Two variables : A categorical variable with a categorical variable

7 Graphing or Plotting data You must ask yourselves these: 1. Which variable do you want to plot? 2. What is the type of that variable? Factor? Numerical? 3. Are you going to plot another variable together? 7.1 One variable: A categorical or factor variable We can create a simple barchart dist.sex<-table(dataSPSS$sex) barplot(dist.sex, main='Sex distribution', xlab='Sex') 7.2 One variable: A numerical variable histogram hist(dataSPSS$age, main = 'Age', xlab='Age in years', ylab='Count') 7.3 Two variables : A numerical with another numerical variable We will use scatterplot to plot plot(dataSPSS$tahundx, dataSPSS$age, main = 'Duration having DM VS age', xlab = 'Duration of DM', ylab = 'Age', pch = 19) Let us make a fit line plot(dataSPSS$tahundx, dataSPSS$age, main = 'Duration having DM VS age', xlab = 'Duration of DM', ylab = 'Age', pch = 19) abline(lm(dataSPSS$age~dataSPSS$tahundx), col = 'red') and a lowess plot(dataSPSS$tahundx, dataSPSS$age, main = 'Duration having DM VS age', xlab = 'Duration of DM', ylab = 'Age', pch = 19) lines(lowess(dataSPSS$tahundx,dataSPSS$age), col = 'blue') 7.4 Two variables : A categorical variable with a categorical variable Now, we will plot 2 categorical variables simultenously. First, we will use stacked barchart compl.sex<-table(dataSPSS$complica,dataSPSS$sex) compl.sex ## ## female male ## no 105 120 ## yes 48 92 barplot(compl.sex, main='Complications by sex', xlab='Sex', col=c('blue','red'), legend=c('No','Yes')) Next, we will use grouped barchart compl.sex ## ## female male ## no 105 120 ## yes 48 92 barplot(compl.sex, main = 'Complications according to sex', xlab = 'Sex', col = c('blue','red'), legend = c('no','yes'), beside = TRUE)
